Details: The color and material of the paper used for proofing and actual printing are inconsistent.
Solutions: Use paper materials consistent with those used for prrofing during bulk printing.

Details: For the same Pantone number, different customers have different hues and formulas.
Solutions: Standardize files so each Pantone number corresponds to a single color and a single file.

Details: Ink thickening or excessive water addition during ther printing process
Solutions: Regularly test ink pH. If above 8.5, add pH adjuster; if below, use water to adjust viscosity and fluid balance.

Details: Ink color perception is affected by illumination angle, intensity, and type of light source.
Solutions: Use consistent lighting conditions and evaluate under a standard color-matching lightbox or D65 light source.

Details: Standard color cards fade or change when exposed to sunlight or other light sources, causing mismatch with printed output.
Solutions: Replace standard color cards regularly and store them in the same environment as printed documents to maintain consistency.

Details: Inaccurate ink mixing due to skill gaps or lack of documentation
Solutions: Provide ink-mixing training and maintain formula archives for frequently used colors.

Details: The ink formulation is unreasonable.
Solutions: Choose appropriate materials and adjust the formula.

Details: The pH value of the ink is below 8, disrupting its balance.
High temperature causes the ink to dry too quickly.
The ink dries too quickly during use
Solutions: Add 2-3% slow-drying agent during ink formulation.

Details: The pH of the ink is below 7.5
Excess acidic water added during preparation
Solutions: Check the ink's pH value every hours during summer to maintain proper balance

Details: Water and amine substances volatilize over time, leading to low pH and high viscosity.
Solutions: Add 0.2-0.5% defoamer and pH adjustment solution

Details: Ink level drops below pump inlet due to insufficient ink.
Solutions: Maintain sufficient ink level to cover the pump inlet

Details: No defoamer added when reusing old ink.
Prevents release of are pressure
Solutions: Reduce viscosity and add defoamer to assist foam control

Details: High proportion of film-forming resin generates foam easily.
Solutions: Add defoamer in small quantities multiple times during printing

Details: Cleaning agent flows into the ink system.
Solutions: Ensure cleaninig agent does not contaminate the ink

Details: Foam-stabilizing leveling agnets are present
Solutions: Add appropriate leveling agents and defoamers

Details: Excessive surface sizing on paper surface
Solutions: Check the paper surface treatment condition

Details: The defoamer is too strong or added in excessive amount
Solutions: Reselct the defoamer or adjust its proportion

Details: Insufficient dispersion of ink or additives
Solutions: Add 1-2% leveling agent and ensure even dispersion.

Details: Ink viscosity below 10s (Zahn Cup #4)
Ink dries too quickly during printing
Printing pressure too low
Fresh scraper causes uneven print on large patterns.
Solutions: Print small patterns first or switch ciolor group

Details: Excess glue on paper reduces ink transfer
Paper absorbs too much water and ink
Solutions: Increase ink viscosity and volume, or use lower line meh/rubber roller

Details: Viscosity too high, slows drying and affects overprint
Solutions: Add 3-5% quick-drying agent and reduce based ink viscosity

Details: Causes uneven ink transfer
Top color fails to adhere properly
Solutions: Increase top color viscosity and pressure; add 1-2% leveling agent

Details: Ink too thick or too thin for screen mesh
High resin content clogs screen
High pressure or aged plate causes blockage
Screen mesh and plate not compatible
Solutions: Match screen mesh to plate type

Details: Plate too soft to hold ink properly
Scraper unable to clean screen effectively
pH drops over time., increasing viscosity
Ink too thick causes jagged edges
Ink dries before proper transfer
Too much pressure distorts edges
Worn plate causes uneven edges
Dust interferes with ink transfer
Slows drying and causes ink to smear.
Solutions: Add 3-5% quick-drying agent or switch to faster-drying ink.

Details: Strip rubs against ink during handling
Ink lacks durability
Overprint layer dries too slowly
Solutions: Use fast-drying ink and reduce base viscosity.

Details: Excess pigment reduces adhesion
Solutions: Use anti-wear ink, reduce pigment, increase antiwear agent.

Details: Ink becomes unstable and prone to fading
Insufficient binder reduces durability
Ink not fully cured or exposed to humidity
No standard method for wear resistance evaluation
Box surface too smooth for ink adhesion
Reduces surface fiction
Insufficient ink coverage on box surface
Solutions: Increase ink coverage or use textured coating

Details: Some pigments have poor light resistance
Bright tines fade faster than dark ones
Overly bright hues degrade faster
These pigments vary widely in lightfastness
Light tones diluted with white ink fade faster
Solutions: Use high lightfast colors for light tones

Details: Rose/purple tones often lack durability
Some pigments contain halogen compounds
Cross-contamintion introduces halogen
Mineral oil present in defoamer
Ink contaminated during handling
